sp.p: By all that's good it was, soon after this my Unkle dies, and left me luckily e're my fault was known, his fortune, but afterwerds finding my self grow big, and fearing scandal I resolved to go to Madrid, and discover all to my Brother; I did so, he knew him, and after having generously forgiven, and desired me to stay here at Bruxells, promised to seek the wronger of my honour, and force him to do Justice, as soon as he had finished his Embassy into France, for which employment he was about that time chosen, and by his Letter now sent he tells me my false friend is come this way towards England, but that he himself will be here to morrow; then, if we can find the right Father, his Penitence restores him, but if not, a jolly Widdow passes on the formal President, seeming at my Unkles suit, tho my own cunning, in spite of my Aunts Machiavilian plotting; and now thou hast heard all, let's home and consult, I know their heads are at it.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: To do you Justice honour would prevail With every man of sense that only heard your tale. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Bondevelt, Kinglove, and Footmen with lights.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: You have now Sir brought me to the door of my house, I will therefore only discourse ye with a word or two more, and then good night. You are Sir a young Gentleman, and I perceive of singular good parts, prosper me 'tis very much, you have not apply'd your self more to business.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Troth Sir, all that I can say • o your worthyness on this matter is, that my Father bred me of his own opinion, which was, that pleasure is the only business a Gentleman should apply himself to.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
Oh vile, you must give me leave then, hearing this, to tell
ye, Sir, your Father was an Epicure, but your Country England is noted by all considerative Nations, for breeding their Progeny in that manner; oh vile notion, a Gentlemans business pleasures, why it should be quite contrary, a right Gentlemans pleasure should be business.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why faith Sir, I must needs own our Countrymen would hardly take such a one for a right Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I believe so, the reason is, because, prosper me, you let your Souls rust with idleness, now my sharp-sighted Father, I thank him, season'd me from the beginning.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Season him, what did he Pickle and Salt him? aside.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I mean he wisely let me know, some of the rough and untoward part of Life in my infancy, my seasoning was the early preparing my body for travel and business; to which purpose, he sent me at seven years old, a Voyage into Greenland for Whalebone.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Now my Father sent me at seventeen to the University.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: To do what, study silly Theories, to lose the solid Practick, learn Bawdy, under the nickname of Philosophy, or bandy Religion about so hard, to be all the rest of your Life an Atheist, — hah, oh vile Management, there's a whole age lost, mispent and neglected; seventeen, why I had almost finisht my Travels by that time.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There's the hint; now will I set his Tongue agog to tell 'em meerly to save my self, the plague of Repartee, what Travels pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Sir, every where, I have Travell'd every where, to the East and West Indies, from thence to the South America, Panama, G •• n • avellica, Lima, and Porto Bello, I have rolled in Silver from the Mines of Potosi, and in Gold from the River de la Plata, and the rich banks of the lake of Parima.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What Merchandizes I beseech ye, Sir, what Commodities did you vend there?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Ah things Sir, that in their nature you'd laugh to hear of, trifles in our parts here, tho there of prodigious value, to wit, Thread, Points, Horns, Catcals, Penny Looking Glasses, Wooden Trumpets, Tin Nutmeg▪grater, Brass, Candles, Saveals, and the like; and then the rare Mechanical invention of Combs, Knifes, Scizzars, Tooth-picks, Thimbles, Buckles, Buttons, Bodkins, with the most ingenious Cork▪screw and incomparable Nut cracker, bring in a Mint, a Mint of Money, there's pleasure for ye, Sir. Prosper me, what greater can there be, than the ingenious over-reaching ones fellow creature in the way of Trade.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: That is, he means cheating ones fellow creature in the way of Trade. Aside.

To do which there are occasions innumerable, would you believe it, Sir, Riches and Treasure flow there so plentifully that I have had my self a Bushel of Silver for a pack of Cards, and a large Ingot of Gold for a little diminutive unmusical Instrument, vulgarly called a Jewstrump.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ay, and if that be'nt a lye, th • n I'm a Dromedary. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: And so, Sir, I with yo • well home. Sirrah, wait on the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The President Bondeveli's house, Gent▪ pray which is it?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: That there, Sir; but here is the President himself —Hah who's here—what, my dear Collonel?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Mum, Kinglove, not a word more, I'm no body. Softly to him. And please your Worthiness, here's a Letter for ye. To Bond.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: For me, Sir — But hold, there's no need of Ceremony, I know the hand, and find now he's but a Footman for all his gaudiness. Reads.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No questions, Frank, till to morrow, only this, as a doughty Hero once said before, I am going where Love and Honour call, return if alive to morrow by twelve.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Speed the Plough, Sir, fare ye well.
Exit King.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, friend, and on my word thou'rt a very lucky fellow; for I had just writ a Letter, which I would have early in the morning sent to the party, in reference to this very affair—here 'tis, be careful, and there's for thy diligence.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Good agen—What Sot is he now, that disparrages the function of a Lacquey, additionally grac'd with the praise worthy industry of a well-bred Pimp, and so forth — here's four Pistoles got in three quarters of an hour, and gad some two years ago in Flanders I should have thought my Collonelship very lucky in possession of but half as much. Van Scopen is seen peeping about.
But money begins to flutter about agen I see now — Stay, how shall I get this and my self convey'd to her, after I have read it without her knowing I have any light in her affair—hah — by good luck yonders my Counterpart
Sees Van Scopen her creature, who without doubt has staid at the door blowing his Nails ever since my curiosity made bold to supply his office; for now I'm sure 'twas he that was intended—I'll accost him—so friend well met.

sp.speaker: Van Sc.
sp.p: It may be so, Sir, it may be not, Sir, tho • l, loll, loll. Sings.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Come, come, for all thy surliness, I'll prove my self thy f • iend — I know thee — know all thy business too—thou stayst for a Letter to carry to Madam Angellica. Why lookee here 'tis for thee—here's the Gentleman too thou art to guide thither, and here's two Pistoles by way of incouragement to diligence—hah — what thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Van Sc.
sp.p: Think, Sir, gad, Sir, I think ye are much in the right, and my diligence shall second your liberality, Sir, immediately. Follow me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Why well said.
Thus spite of Locks and Bars when Iove did wooe,
Almighty Gold ne're fail'd to shower him through.

div.head: Scene I. Angellica's Chamber,
div.stage: Enter Bertran and Madam La Marquise.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: COme prithee my dear, let me have this money, 'tis but a hundred Pistoles, and I may chance to win five hundred.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Ma Chere, in van word den, I will let no mor money go upon shance, shance is de Teefe, de Sheat, de Pickpocket, shance, morbleau, vill empty min purse, if I give you any mor money for Play, min Deare.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Because I had a little ill luck last night, which was look'd upon as a Miracle too by all the Bassett-Table, the most skilful of all the Punts bless'd himself to see't; for during the time of play, I had once from an Alpiew or Paroli, Sept et la va, Quinze et le va, Trent en le va: Nay, once Soissant et le va, and yet lost all at last, but 'twas a thousand to one, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: 'Tis one towsan to one but min Purse get de dam Consumption wid your Trent and Soissant, if I give you mor money.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What for an Accident, Child? No, no, I shall have luck to night I'm sure, for Mr Shuffle-tallies and I'm to be Croupiere; Ill follow the winning Knaves, and get Sept and Quince et le▪va, before another shall make an Alpeiw; but I confess this last time I had the Devil of ill fortune, such indeed that tis almost incredible, I lost a Sept et le va upon an Eighth King.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p:
Morbleau, and voud lose de Kings Revenue, if you play play on, dat is most veritable, dis game is fit for none but de King
and Queen to play at, derefore I speak once more ver true, I have no more Money ver de Bassett.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But I'm ingag'd in honour to meet my Lady Fatly and take my revenge, for 'twas that hideous Punt that won most of my Money—I'll tell thee how 'twas, Child, she fass'd me every Card I set, or when I drew a lucky one it did not go: she'd make Paroli and Sept e le va upon the same Card, and when • lost my King four times in one deal, she upon an odious filthy Knave, every time wone▪ Sonica: Did you ever hear the like. Sonica? Oh prodigious! Every time Sonica!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: De divla tak my Lady and Sonica too, vat care I vor —heare dis: come, come, be advise and play no more?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What not have my revenge, shall such a huge Tun-belly'd nasty Thump-cushion, as my Lady Fatly, make her brags she has stripp'd me. No, I'll sell my Skin but I'll have my revenge. Besides, does this consist with your French Honour, Sir, to have me stripp'd and made a jest to the Lords, Gentlemen, and the rest of the Company; 'twould be a very pretty sight, would it not, for them to see me stripp'd?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Yes, Morbleau, dat would be de ver pretty sight, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I mean, made uncapable of another night's play.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Gazoon, I mean so too, I should be ver loth to find dat.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Pish. Pray, Sir, no more of your jests, if you will grant my request, and save my credit, I shall think my self oblig'd, but pray spare your wantton conceits, my virtuous inclinations don't admire 'em?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Madam, I hope I may jest without affronting of your virtue; and I hope I may love you ver well, widout more squeezing min Purse vor de Bassett.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Will you deny me then?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: You set your heart too much upon dis ting, Madam Your love of de Play, mak you covetous, and love Money too well. And dat Wife dat love Money too well, assurement ver often love her Virtue too little.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: 'Tis basely said, if you reflect on me, Sir, whose virtue has been of so pure a nature, it ne're was tainted yet with one bad thought. Virtue as white as Down of Swans or Ermin.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I don't know dat, but to be sure, I have tak de care to wash you a little.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: You will deny me then?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: No, no, no, deny, I will only keep a my Money, dat is all.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I shall be horribly out of humour, I shall scold confoundedly.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I shall sing and laugh den ver mush.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Indeed you had better save my credit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Indeed I had betra save my Money, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Phoo, you shall do it for your little Dear this once; what, hang a hundred Pistoles, I'll oblige you, my dear dear precious, a hundred times as much: Come, you shall hear a pretty new Scotch Song I made —

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p:
Ay, with all my heart. A Dance.
Scotch SONG I.
I.
JOckey was a dowdy Lad;
And Jemmy swarth and tawny
They, my heart no Captive made,
For that was prize to Sawny.
Jockey wooes, and sighs and sues,
And Jemmy offers Money;
Weel, I see, they both love me,
But I love only Sawny.
II.
Jockey high his voice can raise,
And Jemmy Tunes the Vyol;
But when Sawny Pipes sweet Layes
My heart kens no denyal,
Yen he sings, and t' other strings,
Tho sweet, yet only teize me;
Sawny's Flute can only do't,
And Pipe a Tune to please me.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: There's for ye, my Life, my Heart, my Vitals; and now you shall do't for me; I'll do any thing to divert my dear Honey.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Aw you are de dam cunning Gipsey — Here is de Honey, and de Honey, but Gazoon is only for my Money — Aw but dis shall no do for all dat. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And this now my own heart shall command every day if he pleases, and every night I'll sing my own dear asleep.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Aw, pure wheadle, morbleau dis is plain, dis is de meer sheate; ve good den, I vill trye now vor put de sheate upon her.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Come Sweet, shall I be oblig'd to thee? p • ithee say Ay.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p:
Vell, vell, put off your meeting vor one two day, you know I go to morr to receive Money, and sall stay out de
whole night; ven I come home I vill tell you more; but no more to dat purpose, Morbleau: — Aside. So, go go and make your Visit, and present my service to de Lady. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p:
Pish, this is only a sham, this niggardly wretch won't do it I see by his sleering. Well Monsieur, since you dare deny your Wife necessaries, for Money is the chief of necessaries, she shall try what her Merit can do without ye; and whether her Beauty will pawn for a hundred Pistoles; for the truth is, I do love Money so well, and Play for the sake of Money, that I'm resolv'd to keep up my Credit abroad with the Gamesters of Qualtiy, tho his Cuckoldom purchase the means of doing it; and I think I have a Chapman ready too, which I made sure of, for fear he should prove thus hide-bound.
Enter Mascarillo. How now Mascarillo, what news of the Collonel?

sp.speaker: Mase.
sp.p: Why, Madam, I hear there's a Letter left at home for ye, and I suppose from him; but if you would know more particularly, step into the next room and you may inform your self, for he's just gone in to visit Madam Angellica.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Who the Collonel — ar't sure 'tis he?

sp.speaker: Mase.
sp.p: Very sure, Madam, for I saw Van Scopen my Brother Crony bring him in the back way about a quarter of an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What can this mean? I am sure she has no acquaintance with him. Ha, ten to one 'tis after me he comes, having had information of my being here; go and pump the t'other fellow, dear Mascarillo, and bring me what Intelligence thou can • t.

div.stage: He makes sign for Money. She walks off.

sp.speaker: Mase.
sp.p: Very good, I am to Pump for her, and I am to Pimp for her, and yet not a penny of Money; humh — Gad this shan't do? but hold, she is not fit for the Trap yet, let the Mouse play a little longer. Aside, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: My Lady heard you were here Madam, and having this instant some company with her, she commanded me to wait on you into her Bed-chamber, where she will attend you presently.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I am her humble Servant: This shews • he does not care I shou'd see what company is with her; hum — is it so? Well, I'll watch her I'm resolv'd, and if they proceed to an Intrigue, prevent it, tho I ruin he • I'm of a nature that can endure no Competitor. Aside, and Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Dorange and Angellica, with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sir, as the Presidents friend you are welcome to me, and I thank you for the care of his Le •• er; tho you have ventur'd into a place so inhospitable to strangers, that I dare not assure your good usage long.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Madam, the Courtesie I receive from you has oblig'd sufficiently one that has had a character of the nature of this family. Apart. 'Tis she, by Heaven, but the Small Pox has so alter'd me I see she does not know me, which suits well with my design; and though I am welcome as the Presidents friend now, I hope, if things are not gone too far, to prove more my own friend than his very shortly.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What makes him look on me and mutter to himself? Sure he knows something of the Child! Lord help me, how every look or trifle frights me, since that unlucky accident first happen'd. Aside.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: Oh Madam, if you don't intend to have all the things in the Room thrown at your Head, your Eyes pull'd out, and your Clothestorn to pieces, look about you presently, and clear your Lodgings; here's Scopen has run himself out of breath, to bring news from the Stable, that your Aunt is broke out, and is coming like a Fury, her eyes flaming with rage, and her Tongue thundring out dissolution to her Husband, and all that withstand her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Oh Heaven, what shall we do with the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: I know not; she's such a Fiend now she's in her fit, she'll tear him all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The Devil she will; I'll warrant ye, Madam, fear nothing, I'll tame her quickly.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Tame her! O Lord, Sir, 'tis impossible, she has got Firearms and the Devil and all with her; she'll have a brace of Slugs in your guts before you can ask what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Humph▪ Gad I'm like to be finely paid for my postage, if this be true, I'll get out at the back door.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: The plaguee Footman has taken away the Key — No, hold. (Studies.) I've thought of something at a pinch — Your Taylor, Madam, that brought home your Stayes to day, left a Coat here of some bodies, to call for as he came back, and an old Perriwig the Butler can lend him; then, Sir, if you can act a Taylor a little, you may pass securely.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A Taylor, ay, ay, I can act the Devil, any thing, come, • I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Follow me then quickly, for she'll be here in a moment. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Min H. Tomas and Bondevelt.

sp.speaker: Min. H.
sp.p:
Come, Neice, without mincing the matter any longer, if as your Unkle, I have any interest in ye, I desire ye to look on this worthy friend of mine, the Honourable President, in a
particular way, I mean as a Suiter, his place in the State •• eminent, his parts not to be questioned, and to sum up all virtues in one, the greatest promoter of Trade in Europe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sir, I shall always honour your Merits, and in how particular a manner your admission extends, I hope I satisfied you in my Letter.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Madam, you did, which, prosper me has given me a universe of joy. When I was at Qui • o, after coming from the River of Amaz •• s, I saw a Wedding, and the Bridegrooms method of expressing his joy for his Bride was, by slitting his Nose, cutting off one Ear, a joynt of the Ring finger from each hand, and so forth. Ah Madam, I could wish it were the custom here to assure ye, I wou'd not spare the sacrificing any part about me, to shew the grand satisfaction I possess for the honour of your Ladyship's favour.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: His discourse is always so pleasantly larded with his Travels, Niece — oh — the President's an admirable speaker, snick me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I believe no less, Sir, but pray where's my Aunt, did not she come with ye? why we have been frighted here with the alarm of her coming? We have almost been scar'd out of our Wits?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Aw never fear her, I have laid her fast enough — I shall rest in my Bed now, and lay my Legs across as I please; and I think 'tis but reason, for I han't slept soundly this twenty years.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How now? How came you to fright us so, and tell my Woman my Aunt was coming?

sp.speaker: Van Sc.
sp.p: Dsheart, so she is coming, and by this time at the bottom o'th' stairs.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: How, Sirrah, what the Devil is she broke out?

sp.speaker: Van Sc.
sp.p: Broke out, I gad, Sir, and will break your head within this two Minutes—She has arm'd herself like the figure of St. George in the Sign, with a Head-piece on, and a great Iron-headed Pike in her hand instead of a Launce, a huge Sword, with a Basket-hilt, after the fashion of Scanderbeg; besides, a Fusee, and the Devil and all of Fire-arms.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Gad forgive me, Fire arms — Good Sir be pleased to abscond for a moment, I know 'tis you the seeks. Here's a Press used to hang Cloaths up in; in, in quickly, I beseech ye, Sir, whilst I submit my self and calm her fury.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How, Unkle, is this you that us'd to say you would shew your Masculine power, and make her tremble?

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p:
Ah, but the Fusee, Niece, the Fire-arms, if she had come reasonably, that a man might have box'd with her fairly, I'd have given her a squelch, and kept her under me till she ask'd me pardon, but that confounded Fusee, Engine • f the Devil, or wo • se than the Devil to me; a Soldier, I quake at the thought • n't. Annik'y within.
Where are ye, Skellum? where are ye? I shall ferret ye presently.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Ah, 'tis her dreadful voice, snick me. In, in, pray Sir, she's coming up the stairs.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: An odd turn of affairs this, I that have been sixteen thousand leagues off in the wide world, from East to West, to be now confin • d to a Box not above sixteen inches Diagonical, hugh—Tis a strange turn of affairs, prosper me. Goes into the Press.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
I'll get out of hearing I am resolv'd, let them fight their Battle by themselves.
Exit Angellica.

div.stage: Enter Anniky, armed ridiculously, with Head piece, Back, and Breas • , Sword, Half Pike, and a Fusee on her Shoulder.

stage.hi: She stares • t him, and h • looks sneakingly.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p:
Lord, Goodman Assinego, how you • ook now? How does your stomach stand affected, hoh; I have brought ye a relish here of the Diet you design'd me; there, eat.
Throw • him Horse-beans.
Sir, snick and snee me, eat quickly, or Offers to shoot.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: I will eat, I will eat any thing, dear Wife, any thing Eats.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Wife! 'Dslife such another word, and the Sun shines through thee immediately—Wife! familiar fool, my name shall be Tame • lana, as being the first Conqueress and Tamer of a useless insignificant Animal call • d a Husband. D'ye eat, Sir?

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: I do, I do, most invincible Tamerlana, I do. Eats.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: The best repa • t in the world for fellows that are troubled with frigidity. Well, now to Confession; what, you are a Doodle, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: I am so.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Very well. Come, now muster up your offences with an audible voice, and explain your self; begin with your notorious misdemeanour in Wedlock — Come, own first, that whatever you are, you ought to be — a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: I do so.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Leave off that sneaking Dog-look you had best, and speak out, or here's what shall open your pipes.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Oh good Wife. Tamerlana I mean▪

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Go on to the rest then; own, own.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Why, I do own, I do own, that when I marry'd the • first 'twas for thy Money. Crying.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p:
And tho I was indifferently civil the first night, much against my will; and yet I made a horrible resolution in the morning never to be so agen.
Crying • ut▪

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Like a sordid Rascal as I was.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Like a sordid Rascal as I was.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Good, proceed.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: That I always hated that goodly plump person of thine, and being instigated by the Devil, us'd to call thee a fulsome Dowdy.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: For which I deserve to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: For which I deserve to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: In thy Garters at my own door.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: In thy Gar • ers at my own door.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Right. Now to your contrivance with Bondevelt about marrying my Niece—Own quickly, come.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Why, I own I have contriv'd.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: With that Coxcomb the President—Out with the truth, and loudly—as you wou'd keep your Guts whole.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: With that Coxcomb the President—Oh Lord, he hears me now I'm sure, Aside. In consideration of a Bond of three thousand pounds given me, to marry him to my Niece.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: That's well; now come give me that Bond: Come, come, and set your hand here to assign it to me, and I'll condescend to be friends.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Ah, sweet Wife, gracious Wife, gracious Tamerlana, don't exact so hardly upon the Husband of thy bosome, don't Chick.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Nay, no delays or evasion • ; do that or take this; I have Money and Friends enough to get my Pardon for killing a thousand such drones as thou art, and do the State good service into the bargain—Or else come I'll go another way, give me Bond and Judgment to get me an heir by Christmas-day next, and I'll be satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Oons, that's a task ten times harder than t'other Snick me, that's a thing the Devil wou'd not undertake—Come, give me the Paper — There — Writes. Well, are we friends now?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Ay Friends — what else, come kiss me. He kisses her.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Ah Anky, Tamarlana, ah Anky — Away with your Arms then, away with that Murder-maker now.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Well Husband, and d'ye truly She gives him her Arms. forget all now; you know 'twas only a piece of cunning; we are all mortal, • o secure my self, in case thou shou'dst dye, and leave me, Honey. Fawning on him.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Wormwood, Gall.
I see thou hast a frown or two left upon thy forehead still. Come, we'll have some Wine to our reconcilement: Wou'dst thou drink my health in a Bumper of Sherry now, and sweeten it with—.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Ratsb • ne—Come Cockatice, ye are catch'd at last, ye are disb • nded ifaith — Have you laid down your Arms, good Powder-Monkey — Come, deliver — 'Sbud give me the Papers back agen, or —

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Instantly, or snick me my double fist shall so mawl thee — Oh, I lye, I lye, I lye; oh gracious Tamerlana: Goes to seize her, she pulls out a Pistol. I did but jest, I did but jest faith and troth. Kneels to her.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Ah ye treacherous Skellum, is this your reconcilement. 'dlife, why should not I rid my self of such a Scoundrel?

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Oh Tamerlana, Tamerlana, I am at thy feet, I am at thy feet.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: But hang • t, let the fool live, I know always how to keep him in awe. Go, get ye out of my sight and study a repentant Speech, you had best. If I find any more Rebellion, 'tis but thus: Phiz, bounce, your Puddings shall pay for't instantly.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Tarmagant Jade, what a life must I lead now — Oh, I must go and get drunk to cure me of my fright. Oh I am a miserable Burgo-master, snick me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p:
So, here is the Bond, three thousand pounds worth of Paper. However, here's the effect of Wit 'now, this comes of managing Matrimony, as I am a Calvinist: And now I'll to my Niece, I'm sure she is in some of these Rooms, and perhaps the President with her, I care not if he is now, the Fish is caught, I'll go and see.—
If Husbands still are pleas'd when Wives they fool,
Wives must be so, that can their Husbands rule.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
A strange unaccountable Creature this! And I have found since my inclosure in my Hutch here, that this Burgomaster too is a very timorous rascally Fellow: First, to let a sawcy Woman affront me behind my back; and, secondly, to be baffled out of my Bond; but 'tis all one to me who has it, great Benefits are seldom got without good Bribes: And if by either of
'em I get but the Lady and the Fortune, I shall be repaid well enough, therefore I'll venture to go, and shew my self amongst 'em. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Angellica and Gusset with Dorange, dressed like a Dutch Taylor wi • h Womens Stays in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: So this disguise was very lucky

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And very ugly, the Devil take me, as ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p:
Come, come, Sir, 'tis well for you we had it, the Dragons Claws in her fury, would have spoiled your Roman Nose else Sir. — hush — to your Trade — here she comes, and Madam la Marquise with her, whom she has met in the Dining Room: come Sir, look sneakingly and mind your business.
to Dorange.

div.stage: Enter Anniky, and Madam la Marquise.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: How now, what fellow's that?

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: My Ladies Taylor, Mr. Stichwell Madam.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How, how, Madam, not like your Stayes?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No not like them, they pinch me here upon the breast, pucker here on the Shoulde • , and the whalebone hurts me.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: And are not you a foo • Neice, to employ him then; the fellow looks like a Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.p:
Thankee
aside. sees Mad. la Marquise. hah by Heaven the charming Creature, that sent me the Letter this Morning. what a garb has she found me in. aside.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis true Aunt, but he makes some amends by his honesty tho he be a dull Rogue,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Very pretty on t'other side.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: 'Tis the Collonel, I • m sure 'tis he, tho disguised aside.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p:
Here take a Needle and Silk, and gather in this skirt a little straighter— he stares at her. What hast forgot thy Tools ah, thou're a Bungler.
gives him Needle and Silk and he sits down cross leg'd and s • ws aukwardly

sp.speaker: Ann
sp.p: Well, you'll never come into our fashion Neice, you will always wear Armour, and Coats with long Tails that sweep the Rooms cleane • than the w •• ch does; if you wou'd have had my Taylor you had not been so clumsi • y serv'd; 'dliflikins this awkward fellow • ooks as if he ne re hand • ed a Needle in's life.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pox on her she might have swore it, my Fingers are a little numb'd and please ye Madam, 'tis cold weather,

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Well Neice, where have ye hid the President, for I'm sure he was here, — come you may tell me, I am not now so angry at the matter, as I was, so you entertain none but he, tell me the truth where is he?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Then to be • lain with ye Madam, you frighted him
hence, tho he would fain have spoken with you, and I believe he waits for ye now, at your own apartment.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p:
Well I'll go to him, and be moderate, lookee Neice, you know your Brothers order and my power, let me be concern'd in your affairs, and then all will go well, but otherwise not so, as I'm a Calvinist.
Exit Ann.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: So, thank fortune, she's dispatch'd at last. Come, now what think ye of a Game at Cards?

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Pray let the sham Taylor get into his true shape again first, Madam.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay, gad, for I'm plaguee weary of my Trade—You Devil, you puzzled me soundly, about gathering the Skirt there. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Madam, I have a business that calls me home, or else I should be very glad to make one at Ombre, but the Collonel no doubt will march ye at Picket.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: The Collonel! What, then I perceive she is acquainted with him; who can this Collonel be? Aside. You know him then, Madam, pray what Collonel is't?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Why, Madam, don't you know?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Not I: He's an acquaintance of the Presidents, but an utter stranger to me, and this disguise was to keep him from my Aunts knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that. Aside. And to me too, Madam, as to his name, but he's very well worth your acquaintance; he's an English Collonel of Horse I hear, and a man of a very good Family.

div.stage: Re enter Dorange new dress'd, and Gusset.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I believe I shall laugh at this Adventure very often when I han't the happiness of seeing your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: The occasion will require it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
'Tis always so, when we are to be govern'd by Relations. Gusset get the Cards ready.
Exit Gusset.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
And till they come, I beg the favour of a word with you Madam.
To M. la Marquise.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p:
Madam, I beg your leave a minute.
To Angellica. Now for the hundred Pistoles; Fortune, I hope I shall nick his business. aside.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Madam, having been engag'd lately to hear a little tumultuous discourse just now between your Aunt and the Burgomaster, and perceiving at last the main hinge on which the whole matter mov'd was relating to me, I resolv'd to conceal my self no longer, but to discourse her. Is she gone, I beseech ye?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Just gone Sir, a minute since; I'm sure you may overtake her easily; and 'twill be proper, Sir, because now she has a mind to see ye.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
Madam, I understand ye perfectly.
Looks off, and sees Dorange talking familiarly with M. la Marquise. How oddly that Domestick behaves himself. aside. I will therefore instantly go dispatch her as soon as possible, and be with your Ladyship again with my first opportunity.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sir, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
Madam, I have long'd for a Regalia of pleasant Conversation with your Ladyship too—But business, unfortunate business, Madam—
To M. la Marquise, putting by Dorange. How now, how dost do?
Nods at Dor. To Ang. Oh Madam. I had forgot to tell ye before I go, you have really a very diligent fellow of that.
Pointing to Dor. I have found him so; a very diligent fellow, and worthy recommendation—Your Servant Madam
Exit, bowing to the Ladies, and nodding to Dorange.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Diligent fellow! what does he mean? he talks of him as if he were my Footman. aside. Give me the Cards, Gusset.
She s • rts 'em.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: The Presidents great business sure makes him forget his manners; he uses ye very familiarly, Collonel.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh, I know 'tis his way, and am us'd to't—I understand what he means by a nod, as well as a dumb man the language of the fingers: but to the purpose of what I whisper'd, d'ye believe me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What, that you came here purposely to see me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That, or you undo me.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O fie; try if you can perswade me to't; however, as I find you behave yourself like a man of honour, I shall be induc'd to give ye credit; but no more now, the Lady expects ye at Cards.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: By Heaven I'll not fail—Oh damn'd Rogue, now cannot I forbear pursuing this Intreague, tho I lose this other Angel by't, and a flourishing fortune — Oh woman, woman, tempting flesh and blood, how wicked dost thou make us. They sit down to play.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
I forgot to ask her before I went whether I should have any farther private correspondence with her Unkle, the Aunt being, I perceive, Lady of th' Ascendant, and sole Governess of the Family's affairs; but I hope 'tis not too late to be resolv'd—
How now! what's this I see! At Cards—and so familiar with a Footman — Prosper me, can this be real! Observes 'em.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: For the Poynt Madam — fifty seven.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I'm your equal, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Are ye so? I have spent my time fairly then. aside.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your Ladyship has a Qui • t, I suppos • .

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No, indeed Sir I am not so lucky.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Not a Quint? what think ye then Ma ••• of Terse Major?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ve • y good.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
Oh Abominable, 'tis plain now there ••
• n Intreague between 'em, a rank Intreague by Heaven, and I accidentally coming back have surpriz'd 'em, when they thought themselves secure, — oh the P • odigious Appetite of Women, that when the Blood ferments make no distinction, the high born Princely Peer, and the poor Peasant, are equal in their fancies. However I'm glad I saw this, that I may sort a season to inform her how I despise her Amity.
going out meets Gusset.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: I hope your worthyness is not going so soon.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I have staid too long unless in better Company.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: How Sir, what is't you say, better Company!

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Yes 'twas I said it—besides perhaps I might disturb your Lady and the Footman at their Game.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: The Footman, Sir,

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: The Footman, Mistress: 'tis not his fine Coat can make him otherwise, he • s too well known.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: Bless me Sir, he passes here for a Collonel.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: That's a likely matter, I say once more, he's a Footman; and she knows it, to whom within this few hours, I gave Gold to pay him for an Errand, and so I leave her, tell her to her Pastime, and much good do her with her running Gamester.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: How is this a Footman • ; who the Devil would have thought it, I wonder'd indeed he was so over civil, how many raw young Creatures has that Coat now put a cheat-upon.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Seven.—

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: And how many Guinea's will she give me for discovering this now.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Five,—
playing the G • me.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: 'Twould be worth some I warrant from this Scoundrel too to conceal it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Eight.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: To intreague with a Footman, Lord how many Lovers of Quality has she had.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Five.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: And some Rampart Damsels this Cheat has had I warrant too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nine.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: It will deserve ten Guinea's from her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Six Seven.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: And from him to play false.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nine.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: Hah, sure the Impostor does not answer me, but if he did I'll be honest, I know I shall have ten of her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Eight.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: Well Eight with honesty, and for his part.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nine.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: Bragging Puppy, sure he has over-heard me, but I'll cross-purpose him presently. Madam, I beg your pardon for interrupting ye, but I must needs speak with you on earnest business.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What, sure you can stay till the Game's up.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: Not a minute Madam, excuse me, 'tis what concerns your honour.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Oh by all means Madam, I must not be guilty of detaining ye when matters of moment ingage—your most humble Servant, I'll wait on ye another time,—your Servant pretty Creature.
to Gusset.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: Impudence, prithee get thee gone. frowns.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Hey day, what has she left her manners amongst her Ladies foul Linnen, what a pox ails her.
Exit Dorange.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How now, what you did not affront the Gentleman I hope.

sp.speaker: Guss.
sp.p: Gentleman, hang him trotting Horse. Madam, you have been the most damnably impos'd on that ever woman was. In short, this gay Fellow that you have made your Companion, is another Van Scopen, nothing but a Footman.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A Footman! Why, Madam la Marquise told me he was a Collonel, and a man of a very good Family; I know too they generally dress in that manner.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: Pugh, what signifies that, or what she says: Here was the President just now looking over your Play, and in such a passion to see your familiarity, that I could not pacify him; he knows him, it seems, no otherwise but as a Footman, and doubtless was angry, believing some intreague between ye. Tell her, says he, I'll leave her to her pastime, and much good do her with her running Gamester.

sp.speaker: Ang
sp.p:
Was there ever such a mischievous • ccident? What could be the Fellow's design? he never hinted any thing▪ of
Love to me? and I swear did not look unlike a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gus.
sp.p: No, a pox take him, the fellow set a good face upon the matter.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Well, be sure the Porter locks him out for the future; in the mean time go you and find out the truth, and give the President our account of him, but especially let us contrive to keep it from my Aunts knowledge.
With Art and Care, success we now must get,
And since good fortune fails, supply with Wit.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: Prince de Landvile, Knight of the Order of the Fleece, Min Heer Tomas, Bertran, Kinglove, Dorange, with a Cloak on, all as sitting at a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: HA, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
You have very good reason, • aith Sir; when a Wife once comes to be tarmagant and sawcy, she ought to be reprimanded. This is the most comical fellow that ever I met with.
aside to Dor.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh your Highness will have more of him presently; but remember I'm a Merchant. aside. My Lord, I was beginning to tell him an infallible way to be reveng • d of her—What, a jolly Burgo-master, the soul of Trade, and the top of all the Herring Merchants in Brussels, to be as it were imasculated by a Woman; faith 'tis egregious; no, no, take thy Revenge, old Butter-gullet.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Revenge — egh — Zooks I'd give half I'm worth to be reveng'd of her, and t'other full Glass or two will set me purely in for't, Odsbeares: For you must know I an't such a sneaking Pea goose then, as when I'm sober: Odsbeares, I can talk to her then and swear; I am a mettled fellow when I'm drunk, snick me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Why well said, who gives the Burgo-master a Bumper there? Monsieur Marquis, you are his next man, pray see the Glass come to him—Come, here's Confusion to all domineering Wives: Wives that set a greater Tax upon a Husbands virility
than his Constitution is ever able to pay. Here, Confusion to 'em.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Hem; come, away with't; gad I shall be pure and bowzy presently.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p:
Along Monsieur, here is one Bumper to you; and hark you, de healt is, may your Wife break her neck down staire to mor morning.
Dri • ks.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Amen: I'll drink a pint to that, snick me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: As fairly drank as the occasion is honourable. And now, Sir, as you are a Merchant, and a Lover of Trade, you are oblig'd to help a Brother in distress; you were beginning to tell him a pleasant way of Revenge; come, pray let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Ay, come Brother Sprat, prithee out with't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: If it wants more heads than one we'll all help: I'll give thee some drops to mix with her mornings draught shall make her so hoarse for a twelvemonth, that she shall whiz like a Monster shewer in the Fair, and not be heard the distance of two foot, let her endeavour to scold never so violently.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Thankee good Sir, snick me, that would do very well.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: And harkee you Mister Burgomastree, I vill give you one rare Powder, dat shall draw her Tongue out of de Mout, de Teet out of de Head, and de Nayle of de Finger, and ven she can neider scold, bite, nor scrash, she vill be ver good Wife, Morbleau.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Humph—odd that's an admirable Powder too, that's Powder would do mighty well, Sir my service tee. Drinks. but come Brother, prithee now let's hear thine.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why Sir I remember you said some time since, that above all things your Wife hates a Monkey.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: She do's so; nay, and with that Mortal aversion that she'll swoon if it comes too near her, goggle with her eyes, foam at mouth, and play such tricks as if ten thousand Devils had possest her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: There's your way, Sir, whenever you would gain your point, carry one under your Cloak you may fright her to any thing.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Zooks he has nick'd it; 'tis a rare way faith, to get my Bond agen; for the very Devil is not so frightful to her as a Monkey, and I'll carry one always about me, I'm sure 'twill make her do any thing. Odsears, this is a notable man, he carries a great deal of Docity, egh — under that Cloak there. Kecks

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: So, his joy for his Monkey and the last Bumper together, have almost foxt him; 'twou'd be pleasant to see him and his Wife when they meet now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Pleasant, 'twou'd be an admirable Scene for a Comedy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: See, he's going to tak • t'other Bumper upon't.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: He will be more dru • k for joy of his Monkey, den he vas when Peace vas proclaim.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay, or at the safe •• urn of the Smirna Fleet, tho he had never so great a share i • ' • . So, Sir, by your smiling I see you like my project.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Like it! I cou'd kiss th • e, faith and troth; but stay, where shall get I this Monkey? hum — Oh, Odsears, well remembred, my Niece has a rare one, which she keeps up always privately for her own diversion, that shall be • t faith, and I'll go get it instantly, for I'm resolv • d to have my Bond again. Dear Brother, I thank thee once • ore heartily for thy project, and your good Lordship for my • r • at. And so, egh—but hold, my Lord, my Lord, one G ••• s more faith, here's— egh — my Neices Monkey's health, my Lord. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Oh, with all my hea • t Sir, and to the rest of your Relatio • s, if you please, Mr Bu • go master.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: And so sit ye merry; I am egh— almost drunk faith. Odseares if I light on Ańniky now she's a miserable Jade, snick me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha — now he's gon vee sall lose de ver fine humeur, sneeka me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And snick me, now he's gone too, there lyes my Merchandize. Throws off the Cloak.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: My Lord, the Musick your Lordship order'd wait below to know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Let 'em come up. Come Gentlemen we'll have a Song.
The New Reformation. A Song.
I.
NEw Reformation begins through the Nation
And our grumbling Sages, in hopes of good wages, Direct us the way.
Sons of the Muses▪ then • loak your Abuse • ;
And lest you s •• uld tr • mple on • ious Example, Observe, and Obey.
Time-frenzy Cu •• rs,
And stubborn Non-Iurors,
F • r want of Employment, now s • urge the l • wd times:
They've hinted, they've Printed,
Our vein is, Prophaneness,
The worst of all Crimes;
Dull Clod-pated Ralliers,
Smiths, Cobblers and Colliers,
Have damn'd all our Rhimes.
II.
Under the notion of zeal for Devotion,
The humour has fir'd em, or rather inspir'd 'em
To Tutor the Age:
But if in season, you'd know the true reason,
The hopes of Preferment is what makes some Vermin
Now Rail at the Stage.
Cuckolds and Canters,
With Scruples and Banters,
Th' Old Forty One peal against Poetry ring.
But let State revolvers,
And Treason-Absolvers,
Excuse if I sing
The Sconndrel that chooses
To cry down the Muses,
Would cry down the King.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: D'ye hear Musick, flourish all when I drink this health, To the Great Umpire of Christendom, Genius of the War, and all our brave Confederate Princes; Saviour of our Lives, Honours, Liberties and Estates; and eternally renown'd Procurer, Finisher, and Protector of our glorious Peace, his Sacred Majesty of Great Britain. Drinks, and Musick flourish.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: May he be dam dat refuse I say, Morbleau.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay Marqui this is not all yet, the next must be your Masters health, the Most Christian King, then our Mistresses, and then—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: To reel into a Chair, Collonel, that's the next then I'm sure. But now ye talk of Mistresses, harkee, does the Intreague I know of hold to night, are the hundred Goldfinches to fly?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Love will oblige me to fly thither, but I hope her generosity will spare the rest, for all my jesting; however, I'm resolv'd to offer the hundred.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Nay Gad if you offer the hundred, 'tis a hundred to one but she'll resolve to take 'em.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Pardeu she be dam Jilt dat take de hunder Pistole from de Collonel, be who she vill; do I know her?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Faith I can't tell; but if you do, I'm sure I don't; for I never so much as ask'd her name; but she's pretty as an Angel, and witty as 'tis possible; and if she has an ingredient of old Sa
• an mixt with these, and is mercenary, she only runs the risque of my hate after the business is over; but for the present I have no forecast.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Ah, she vill be shenerous no doubt, and so I vish de bon pastime wid all min heart, ha, ha, ha, dear Collonel.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Stay friend, I think it most proper to send my Complement to the Prince before I enter, having been so fatigu'd with business, that I could not wait on him here at dinner, in compliance to his generous invitation— Ay, do so friend, prithee go to him, and present my most humble—

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Sir, you should have told me before; y'are in the very Room now, and yonder the Prince sits amongst the rest of the company.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
Od • o, he's in the right — Well, say nothing then.
Sees Dorange. Heavens — is it possible, sure my eyes are not defective! is not that yonder that impudent Footman with 'em, that I lately found so familiar with Angellica? It is, it must be he, and laughing and prating like a Companion.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Prithee, my Lord, reach the Glass; I'll begin another health.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Impudent Dog! he'll begin another health! Why, what a shame is this, when Noblemen debase themselves to mix with Grooms and Vassals: Bless me, what will this world come to—I'll introduce my self — My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Oh Mr President your humble Servant. I wanted ye extremely at Dinner, but your perpetual business debars your friends still of their expectations.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
My Lord, your Lordships command to me is always business. Ah Sir—
To Kinglove, pushing Dorange away.
Prithee fellow give way, I am glad to see you in the Prince's company.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
What, is he drunk?
To Bertran.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I canno tell; I wondra de Collonel noe give him one grand kick, morbleau.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
And harkee, if occasion will permit —
whispers King.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: He takes me for a Footman. Softly to the Prince. Pray carry it so that I may pass for one, there's an admirable design in't, which you shall know hereafter.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Enough, it shall be done. Whispers the rest,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I have it.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, — oh 'tis ver well. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Now my good Lord, when goes your Lordship for Holland.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Not till Winter, Sir; I intend f • rst to wait upon King William in England, Sir—you may vail you • Bonnet now if you please, you'll be taken for my Bed-fellow a • on else.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Prosper me, my Lord, I had taken him for such indeed, but that I know him.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Ah, 'tis a Gentleman that gives us sometimes the favour of his Company — he pays his Club here — ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh your Lordship's merry — I see now this was only allowance, a frollicksome humour to make mirth, and yet had I just now a message from Angellica, full of seeming wonder, that I should mistake his quality so, he coming there as such a one, and by my interest; I know not what she means, but am resolved I'll carry him to her, and there his quality will be proved. Apart.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I hear amongst the rest of the news, that fame is proud of, that your worthiness has a design to marry.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay gad, and I hear 'tis to a particular acquaintance and intimate friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
Scoundrel — prosper me, but now this fellow begins to be too sawcy, I fear he will put me into a passion.
To King▪

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, he's thus free with us all, he makes no distinctions, 'tis his humour.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
'Tis an undecent humour, and were I to converse much with the Prince, I would argue him out of it. There is one of your Country Proverbs, which I remember, very pertinent to this purpose, which is, Play with a fool at home, and he'll play with you in the Market place. I think it wants no application: Not but I can wink at his folly my self now, having some present business with him—Dost hear, fellow?
To Dorange.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Very well, fellow.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Audacious Rogue. To the Prince

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Ay, he's a very strange fellow, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Well, I know thee, and answer as thou pleasest, so thou wilt do me one piece of service. 'Tis this, that thou wilt go with me instantly to visit the Lady I found thee at Cards with yesterday, for a private reason known only to my self, and I will give thee something to pay thy club hereafter with men of quality.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'll do it, and will it spend afterwards upon thee in what liquor thou lik'st, Bully Rock. Strikes him on the back.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha. They all laugh.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha — This is as I could wish, for I have been deny'd entrance lately, and long to know the reason. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: My Lord and Gentlemen, I hope you will honour me with your presence, I know ye are all admirers of fine Ladies, and I'll beg your opinions of this.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: With all our hearts, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I'll shame her before all the world. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Min H. Tomas Drunk, with a Monkey.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Come pug — egh, come along, by thy notable assistance, and my — egh, potable endeavours, I make no doubt but to make a fool of my Wife, therefore thus I embrace thee —I find now 'tis true as the old saying is, that 'tis good to have a friend in a corner, and in the Chimney-corner I found thee, the best friend I ever had in my life, snick me, for thou canst cunjure out the Devil that possesses Wedlock, and let the poor Vermin feed at ease that's inclos'd — egh — in the Conjugal Mouse-trap. Why how now, Pug—thou laugh'st to hear me call't a Mouse-trap — Very well, Monkey-face, thou wouldest not be so merry if thou wer't married, for I tell thee, for all thy grinning, 'tis a Mouse-trap, a very Mouse-trap, and not only so, but often baited with damn'd mouldy Cheese, that choaks a man into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Lord, Unkle, the priviledge you give the President will bring us into a strange premunire presently, if my Aunt knows it▪ for he's coming yonder with a whole Train of Gentlemen a •• er him. What he intends, I know not, but I'm sure my Aunt watches perpetually to see who comes in, and if she finds 'em here we shall have a horrible House.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Oh, I warrant thee, Niece, I warrant thee, here are some that shall be nameless—as egh—horrible as herself, that shall make their Party good with her, I warrant ye; but in the first place, prithee lend me thy Keys, to lock my reliever here into the Closet, that I may have him forthcoming upon occasion, and then I defy thy Aunt, egh—and all her Imps, snick me.

div.stage: Enter Bondevelt, Prince, Dorange, Bertran, Kinglove, and Gusset.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p:
Madam, you sent me an account to day by your Chamber-diligence there of this most renown'd person,
Bowing to Dorange. both a specimen of his Character, and an affirmative
of his Quality, to shade no doubt from my shallow understanding, the intimacy I saw between ye yesterday. My visit to your Ladyship therefore now is, to confirm before your Unkle, and the Company here, your honourable proceedings, and admirable choice of a Play fellow.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sir, you will do very well to confirm it, for my own part I shall not repent of my proceedings, till I have a worse account of my Play fellow.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir, tho you wear no Sword, I shall borrow one for ye▪ if your busy head vent any thing reflecting on my honour.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: The old impudence—his honour—my Lord did your Highness hear him,—ha, ha, ha,—his honour.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—ay, Sir, he holds it up still.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: A strange odd fellow, Sir, he'll disgrace ye before your Mistress, if you han't a care.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Oh, that's impossible — if my word were invalid, you can give her knowledge enough of him.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Yes, yes, if she would know his merit or qualities —we can do him ver good justice.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Mr Burgo-master, you once thought me worthy of a favour from your Niece, but she has since thought better of that lac'd Coat there, than my civil Robe. Pray look on your Nephew that is to be, dee know him. They stare at one another.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Odsears, who have we here, egh — why what my Brother Sprat Merchant of Peru, what are ye come to put off your Oleaginous Ware to my Niece, dress'd like a confounded Soldade, humh?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A plague of his memory, I thought he had been too drunk to distinguish now; no faith, Sir, I only come to know if you remembered the Monkey.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ye cunning thief, egh —I do remember it, and do you remember too, that your project for me then has brought ye off the danger of your project upon my Niece now. We have Horse ponds and Blankets for Fortune-stealers, ye cunning Dog.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What, the Coat is known then, 'tis reasonable the Ambassadors Livery should be familiar here.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: The Ambassadors Livery, • oons 'tis the Devils Livery, a Soldiers. Pox on thee, put it off, egh— gad I can't abide to look on • t, and prithee be as thou art, a Merchant of true blue Protestant Sprats, monopoliz'd to thy self from Coquimbo, Copiago, Porto Bello, and the Devil knows where.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What in the • ame of Mystery does he mean? he must needs know his Nephews Footman.
A Merchant in that dress, what Riddles this, my Lord you can inform us I'm sure, he's your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: He is so, Madam, and when he thinks it convenient, we are ready to expound his Mystery.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There are some people above the vulgar, that may own him without scandal.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Yes, tru • y, I have seen him sit wid his Hat on among ver good Shentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Enigma's still more riddling — sure this is not the Czar of Musc • vy disguis'd, that they make such caution of discovering him — oh here comes one I'm sure will unravel all.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: So, Niece, is this your compliance to your Brother's Authority and my Commands — hah, but I know this is not so much your doings, as Sir Assinego's there—What is your Article with me out of date already, friend — Have you forgot Tamarlana's power, and your horrid Oaths to encourage no mans coming here without my knowledge—'tis very well I'll, have a Bone for you to pick presently, you shall gnaw for this as I'm a Calvinist.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: The Jade has a Pistol in her pocket now I know, but I'll keep the wind of her till the Company's gone, and I can get Pug out, and then I defy her, snick me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Gentlemen, pray what business have you here with my Neice, for I must tell ye, till I know it, and you make an interest with me you are not welcome, this Gentleman indeed has my suffrage by vertue of his merit, and this Bond here, but you, if you come by another authority, may walk out, she shall hear nothing from ye.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Madam, my Lord and these Gentlemen came at my request to discover a new Suitor of your Niece's: Here Monsieur Enigma, but since I find them shy of it, I desire the favour from you; pray what is this doubty person, Madam?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Hey day, why who's here, the High and Mighty Signior Stitchwell, Viscount Bodkin, and Baron Thimble. Why how now, Sirrah, what Roguery are you designing in this dress? hah.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: So, she thinks she has stitch'd me too. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: The Lady there affirms he's a person of quality, pray let his qualities be made publick. Come, pray declare, Madam—What is he?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: What is he, why he is a Taylor.

sp.speaker: Pr. K. & Bert.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha Loudly.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p:
A whimsical, unthrifty, Maggot-pated Rascal, that has put
on some Of ••• ers Clothes, that's his Customer, only that he might brag that once in his life time he lookt like a Gentleman. What say you, Sir Christopher Cros • leg, are not you a Taylor?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Why ye • itty, spindle shank'd, white liver'd, oyly-fisted, bot • herly Cuckold, did not I see you with my Niece's Stayes in her Chamber to day?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: And have you the impudence then, Sirrah, to say you are no Taylor; if not, what Trade are ye, and be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A Cuckold maker.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Oh rare Tom Thimble, here is an impudent Rascal for ye.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: This is more intricate still, I can't understand either of 'em. Harkee, come hither, did not you bring me a Letter lately for which I gave you Money, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, and are not you one of the Ambassadors Retinue, a Footman, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: What a Devil art thou then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Misanthropos — I hate impertinent Mankind — This Madam may satisfy you, pray
gives Angellica a Ring.
give it to your little one to play with. Aside. But if you must know more, Sir, for once, let these Philosophers expound me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, in a word, he'is a Collonel of Horse, his Name is Dorange, a Gentleman of a very ancient Family, Sir William Dorange's Son of Norfolk.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What do I see, by Heaven, the very Ring I gave the Author of my once forfeited honour,—oh I faint. Gusset leads her off.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
The rest you shall know hereafter: and then perhaps the Gentleman, Lacquey, Sprat-Merchant and Taylor, may be qualified, if affronted to pull you by the Nose, Sir,
to Bond. I must now follow my Love affair, I find by my Watch my intrigue with my beauteous unknown is to be within this half hour, I am a Rogue for leaving this in such a confusion, but t'other is such a darling Temptation, that I cannot avoid, tho I repent all my Life after, apart, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You know where I lodge Collonel, if any thing happens, Command my Sword and service,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And mine—Come Monsieur Marqui, shall we set you down?
〈◊〉 Sire, I tank you I am oblige anoder way upon one grand affair. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: I am amaz'd, and I fear fool'd into the bargain, but I must have the rest on't, for to know this, and no more sets me on the Rack.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: I'll after and piece up the matter, for I find here has been pl • guy tricks and contrivances, but I'll have no private doings with my Niece without me, I'll not give up that authority however.

div.stage: Enter Min Heer Tomas, with a Monkey.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: But you shall.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Oh the Devil the Devil—oh, oh,— falls into a Chair.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Why lookee, the Truth is—here is the Devil—and egh, there is his Dam, and when I've lock'd the door I intend to m • ke ye better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Oh dear Husband, dear Husband, put it out of the Room, or I s • an't live three minutes.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: I dont care three Stivers, if thou dost not live, egh —one.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Dear Husband.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Husband, snick me, such another word as that, and I'll whisper in's Ear, to go and give thee a Buss— Husband, egh—ye sawcy Gil-flirt — no, my name shall be Don Dominario, from my subjecting and making truckle under me a Devil of a Wife, and so to take state accordingly. Rise, and give your Betters place, Hussy. Goes and sits with the Monkey in the Chair, she starts out.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Ay withal my heart most noble Husband — Dominario I mean, is there no way to get out, oh how I tremble. aside.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Now lookee, tho my Friend Pug here asks ye no questions, 'tis not egh for want of copious capacity, but to egh ease himself, and therefore leaves ye wholly to my examination, upon which he will c • a • er his judgment,—come, what have you to say for your self,—what you are a Heteroclite I suppose now?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: I am so.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Good, come then, now in your own words muster up your offences with an audible voice; egh — come explain your self, and begin your most notorious misdemeanor in Wedlock, to which purpose own first, that several times on several occasions you have properly deserv'd egh — to have your bones broke.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: I do so sobbing.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p:
Good agen, well now go on to the rest, and leave blubbering and screwing your face, you had best, for if Pug should see that, he'd think you were making faces at him, and fly at ye
like a Devill — snick me, therefore own, own quickly▪

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Oh—gad, what shall I do, this is intollerable, why I do own, I do own, that when we first married, I was in Love with another man, and that upon the wedding Night I would have made ye a Cuckold but I could not. Sobbing.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Like a notorious Jilt as I was.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Like a notorious Jilt as I was.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: So proceed, Odsears I have her at a rare advantage. aside.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: That my not trying other men since, to get me an heir was not for want of my inclination but theirs, and the less grift was brought to the Mill, the more still I put you to hard Labour.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: For which I deserve to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: For which I deserve to be hang'd. sobbing.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: In my Garters at my own door.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: In my Garters at my own door. crying out.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Right, and that I did insolently plunder my Lord and Master Dominario aforesaid, of a Bond and Assignment of three thousand Pounds, which I now beseech him upon my knees to receive agen,—and pardon me,—Come out with't, and instantly, or here's one shall fetch 'em out of your Pocket, snick me.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Oh, which here upon my knees, I give him agen, throws the Papers. and the Devil do him good with 'em, oh, I'm at my witts end.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Oh, you Servant good Anniky, and now you may go if you please, • bout your business, and brag what a gives the Key. doodle and Assinego you made of me, ha, ha, ha, but hold well remembred faith, let me see, turn out your Pocket before you go, let me see whither your Gun-room be clear, have ye no Fire Arms about ye.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Only this which I was going to throw away indeed Husband. pulls out a Pistol, he starts

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: A Pistol, away with it ye Devil instantly, or I'll bring. Pug to bed to thee to Night—Ah ye Cockatrice, she throws it away. ye Crockadile were ye stealing away with that indeed,—'tis well I had a memory she'd have had my Papers agen before morning else, as soon as ever I had parted with my second here, I had been challeng'd for 'em at Sword and Pistol.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p:
Curse on him, if he had not found out this Monster to plague me, I had kept him always under, but now he has me at his • eck, and may do what he will, which to a Wife, that has before been always uppermost, is in-supportable
we • ps.
'tis a sad Story, but 'tis true, for I can no more indure the sight
of that odious Devil above here, than I could of the t'other below, as I am a Calvinist. Exit.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: So, here they are once more, ha, ha, ha, this makes me merry, and now thanks to my dear releiver, come Buss Buss. kisses the Monkey.

sp.speaker: Van Sco.
sp.p: Sir there's great News since you were below Stairs, my Master the Ambassador is newly return'd, and just gone up into his Sisters Chamber.

sp.speaker: Min H.
sp.p: Odfears, he must not know of my Agreement with the President till I have made sure of the Money—egh—well I'll go to him, come dear Friend let's along, Buss, Buss. Exit.

sp.speaker: Van Sco.
sp.p: How now Brother in iniquity, what in haste?

sp.speaker: Masc.
sp.p: Yes faith, like a Pot that's boyling over, is my Master here.

sp.speaker: Van Sco.
sp.p: No, gone some time since, and I think he said out of Town, why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Matter? why the great matter of the world, ye Rascal, matter of Hornifying ye Scoundrel.

sp.speaker: Van Sco.
sp.p: What, the Collonel resolves then to answer her Challenge; and wilt thou betray 'em, Rogue?— Wilt thou spoyl sport?

sp.speaker: Masc.
sp.p: Why, ye unconscionable Rogue, wou'd you have me Pimp for nothing; 'Sdeath she's as niggardly as a Usuring Jew, her Soul lives in an Alley, and gad if she were a Cherubim I'd betray her if she has no sense to reward Diligence— Yonder they are faith—close as Pigeons, and I am going to bring my Master to breakfast on 'em.

sp.speaker: Van Sco.
sp.p: There will be some blustring in our family too now the Ambassador's come home; I believe the President will be routed when the Father of the Kid's known.

sp.speaker: Masc.
sp.p: Angellica deserves to be befriended because she's generous; but my covetous Devil at home lets Money stick to her fingers like Bird lime; there's no getting it from 'em; she thinks she • s secure of him till to morrow noon, but I know where he's gone, and will ferret him away faith—he'll reward me with a Piece or two I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Van Sc.
sp.l: What curst unhappy hours does he behold,
Who to be prov'd a Cuckold pays his Gold?

sp.speaker: Masc.
sp.l: On t'other side how wisely Gold is paid
To one well gifted in the Pimping Trade:
'Tis Art sublime — for as a learned Poet said,
Pimping the Mind inures, and does prepare
For Politicks, as Hunting does for War.

sp.speaker: D. Leon.
sp.p: YOu are then assur'd 'twas he.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: I can't mistake, Sir, this Ring he gave me, which I know was mine, and by him taken from me that fatal Night, besides his Stature and his Tone of Voyce, tho the Small-pox have altered much his features, and his hair then wore uncut chang'd for a Peruke, confirm him for the Man.

sp.speaker: D. Leon.
sp.p: And Sister did he make such haste out d'e say, when he had shewn this Ring?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Vanish'd immediately, e're I had time to rally my lost Spirits, sunk in a swoon at such unlook'd surprize, he disappear'd, leaving only these few words softly with the Ring, this Madam may satisfy you, pray give it to your little one to play with.

sp.speaker: D. Leon.
sp.p: How should he know of that?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I cannot guess what way, unless the Nurse be false.

sp.speaker: D. Leon.
sp.p: Furies and Fire, give it your little one, that looks all insolence, neglect and scorn, as if he brav'd ye with his lucky Treachery, or as ye since were serv'd so by some other.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I could not understand him, I confess and had no time to Argue.

sp.speaker: D. Leon.
sp.p: I'll find time, and force his best occasions to wait on it, to make him clear the blot that stains my Honour, or in his lustful heart imprint my wrongs, so deep that all our Family shall read 'em, and own I have reveng'd an injur'd Sister.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Oh, if you ever lov'd me, dearest Brother, add not to my misfortune by a greater, endangering your self in any quarrel, there are much milder ways.

sp.speaker: D. Leon.
sp.p:
I'll warrant thee I'll use 'em,—I'll find out Bertran, by him send a Letter to Dorange, then as he answers nobly I'll proceed. apart.
If reason justly can delay the Fight,
'Tis well, if not my Sword shall do me right. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Dorange unbotton'd, and Madam la Marquise in a Nightdress. A Table and dressing box by.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I wonder where this lazy fellow is, some body has been knocking at the Gate this good while; stay here, dear Sir, a little till I go and see, Il'l be with ye instantly, I know my Husband is secure till noon, and you shan't go yet I am resolv'd. Indeed 'tis too early▪ Exit Madam.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Too early did she say, to go—rather too late that I repent my coming, now things are weigh'd in just consideration—What a vile Creature is ungovern'd man, when meerly his own natural heat can change him into a fulsome Idiot. I have left now the fair Angellica, half dead with doubts; nay, and two thousand pound a year in Posse, to give a hundred Pistoles to a Jilt for one nights Lodging, for whieu— 'tis gone— y'are paid, and shake your empty Pockets. Am not I then an Idiot? Faith Collonel Coddle, I am afraid you are. Besides, Angellica was beautiful as an Angel—but then the Child, that is indeed a Thorn which pricks with jealousy; but why should I suspect it is not mine, 'tis likely and reasonable, and consequently her Estate mine too by owning it-and yet I've am left her; Idiot, Idiot still. As for this Creature, now my judgment's cool, my Tongue cannot express how much I hate her. And yet the Jilt is pretty too, but mercenary to such degree, she'd kiss for Gold a Negro, and get a Brat to make the Devil a Page of. When I first gave my Purse, foolishly thinking she would refund two thirds back, if not all, no juggler ever play'd his Cups and Balls with such a slight pass, presto—it was gone, at which my heart gave m • so strange a thump, as if 'twere coming to my head to break it, or rail at me for my egregious folly—humh—let me think, with what was in that Purse, and little more, a Man might buy a House, with Acres and a pretty Orchard to't, to live in Fresco, at—A hundred Pistoles, 'twould buy a Horse to charge against the Turks, break through their Ranks, and trample down a Bassa. 'Twould do a hundred things — indeed any thing—And what have you done with it, Collonel— Nothing. You have play'd a game at Hide and Seek with it, and now can neither find that nor yourself. A hundred Pistoles — well, here, here, they lie. This Box (takes up the Dressing Box.) contains the treasure of my folly— hah—if e're you could dispence with plunder, Collonel, what think ye now — But see, that very word, like some great charm, has drawn her Carcass up to look ou't for her Soul.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Oh dear Collonel, I am at my wits end, this idle fellow is gone out, no one knows where, and my Husband, unlook'd for, coming back, has been knocking at the Gate this half hour, the Maid's just gone to let him in.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A hundred pound in Gold, a lusty Purse indeed.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Oh for Heaven's sake, dear Sir, get into that Closet immediately, and I'll contrive to get him away as soon as I can—Bless me, how you stand—'Dslife if ye don't go in quickly he'll come and catch ye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A lusty Purse indeed. Did e're so much in so short time, from one poor Cully bleed.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, what dee mean? is this a time for tuning, why my Husband's just coming up stairs. Goes to the Stairs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Gad I've a great mind to stay and see who this Cuckold is, then stand buff to him, and try to take my Money again, but it may be she'll get him off quickly, and give me new occasion to make her compound. I'll try her once more. Exit into the Closet.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Good morr, Madam, you rise ver early dis morning.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Ah my dear, you know I can never sleep soundly when you are out of the way, but I confess I did not expect ye home quite so soon.

sp.speaker: Masc.
sp.p: That I dare swear you did not, nor desire it neither. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Has any extraordinary business happen'd my dear?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Yes, yes, ver extraordinary business.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Come, I know ye have brought me the money now, I'm sure you have.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Yes, yes, widout doubt, you will be paid for your great kindness.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Prithee what business Child, I am one half of ye, ye know, and I can't rest till I know what accidents happen'd to t'other. Claps his Cheek.

sp.speaker: Masc.
sp.p: Ah, very pretty wheedle, coakes him there—Now would I swear by this she had certainly made him a Cuckold, tho I had known nothing of the matter. Bert. peeps about the Room.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What is't you look for, my dear.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Vor de Birds-nest, but gazoon, I perveave dey be all fledge and flown away.

sp.speaker: Masc.
sp.p: Into the Closet there, Sir, no further; search there and you may find one with his Feathers on, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: That Villain has undone me, what shall I do. Aside.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Come, Madam, let me see de Key, dere is one Papier dat I must have presantlee, dat concern me ver much.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: The Key indeed, Sir, the Key, the Key, the Key is lost; Sir, I am just sending to have another made, you may have it at night, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: At Night, oh ver good, you are vor de Night work still Madam, but I have now occasion vor de day, de Sun fall shine upon your grand grand vertue, vertue, dat is you say of such pure Nature, it ne're was tainted yet wid one bad Tought, vertue as white as down of Swan or Ermine fall glitter in de day light, hey Sirrah, go take de Fork from de Shimmine aud breaka open de door.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: Yes Sir, gad I'll desire my Master to let me be at board wages for the time to come, I shall have my Meat sawe'd with Ratsbane else, I see by her looks—come let's see, gets a Fork. what conceal'd Vermin is here that's eating my Masters Cheese.

div.stage: Thumps at the door to open it and Dorange speaks.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Dee hear there, who dares to touch the door once more to open it is a Dead Man that minute.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Hah vat is dat.

sp.speaker: Masc.
sp.p: Oh Lord dee hear Sir,—there's one within says, he that touches the Door to open it, is a dead Man.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Ver good, dere is some body den, who is it in de name of vertue, I beseech you Madam?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Indeed Sir some Thief I'm afraid, that has had some private notice of my Jewels that are there.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I have a Pistol charg'd in one hand, and a good Sword in t'other, therefore keep off. Mascarillo lets the Fork fall, and starts.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Hugh, wat do he say?

sp.speaker: Masc.
sp.p: He says he has a Pistol charg'd in one hand, and a good Sword in t'other.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: Vell, vell, dat is not matra Morbleau, so have I, go Sirrah and bid him come out, and if he can shew de reason how he deserve it I will give him de Shentleman satisfaction fairly, tell him dat Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Masc.
